4 DISCUSSÃO

A avaliação das percepções individuais dos indivíduos com transtornos de ansiedade é um fator importante no desenvolvimento de tratamentos mais personalizados e eficazes. O presente estudo é o primeiro a permitir comparações sistemáticas das percepções da doença entre participantes com TOC, TAS e TP por meio de um questionário padronizado. Embora os grupos não tenham diferido em termos da duração percebida dos sintomas, das consequências previstas, da coerência e das emoções associadas às doenças, os participantes com TP acreditavam que o estresse era a causa do seu problema de saúde mental e o percebiam como menos controlável, tanto no que diz respeito à autorregulação quanto à regulação por meios terapêuticos, quando comparados aos outros dois grupos.

O fato dos participantes com TP atribuírem sua doença ao estresse com mais frequência do que os participantes com TAS é consistente com estudos anteriores que relacionam o estresse ao TP (ALBERT, MAINA, et al., 2005, FARAVELLI, 1985, MANFRO, OTTO,et al., 1996, MOITRA, DYCK, et al., 2011, SCOCCO, BARBIERI, et al., 2007). É importante notar que, de acordo com os resultados encontrados, a percepção do estresse como causa do TP foi parcialmente dependente dos níveis de sensibilidade à ansiedade. Schmidt e colaboradores (1997) apontaram o aumento da sensibilidade à ansiedade como preditor de ataques de pânico em indivíduos submetidos a treinamento militar estressante. No entanto, dado o desenho transversal deste estudo, não seria possível determinar neste ponto se o aumento do estresse levaria ao aumento da sensibilidade à ansiedade ou vice-versa (SCHMIDT, LEREW, et al., 2000). Apesar disso, há razões para suspeitar que a sensibilidade à ansiedade torna os indivíduos com TP mais vulneráveis aos efeitos do estresse (KLAUKE, DECKERT, et al., 2010), como enumerado a seguir.

Em primeiro lugar, embora não se tenha conhecimento de nenhum estudo comparando diretamente o TP, o TOC e o TAS em termos de sensibilidade à ansiedade, o fato de o TP estar associado ao aumento da sensibilidade à ansiedade foi amplamente replicado por diferentes estudos meta-analisados (OLATUNJI, WOLITZKY-TAYLOR, 2009). Em segundo lugar, a sensibilidade à ansiedade confere maior vulnerabilidade para o desenvolvimento de ataques do pânico quando combinado a exposição a altos níveis de estresse diante de eventos aversivos (ZVOLENSKY, KOTOV, et al., 2005), inclusive em indivíduos sem histórico de sintomas prévios de pânico (SCHMIDT, ZVOLENSKY, et al., 2006). Em terceiro lugar, o papel desempenhado por eventos estressores na ocorrência de TP em indivíduos suscetíveis foi sugerido por diferentes autores. Embora esteja além do escopo deste estudo revisar esta literatura, uma pesquisa recente concluiu que eventos de separação/perda estão mais fortemente associados ao TP entre indivíduos adultos que tiveram maiores adversidades na infância (ASSELMANN, STENDER, et al., 2018).

Em consonância com estudos anteriores avaliando eventos traumáticos, os indivíduos com TOC e TAS não diferiram em termos de percepção do estresse como causa de sua doença (FONTENELLE, DOMINGUES,et al., 2007). No entanto, em contraste com as previsões feitas neste estudo, os participantes com TOC não atribuíram com mais frequência seu problema a causas biológicas. Diferentemente do que costumava-se acreditar, a atribuição da etiologia dos transtornos mentais a fatores biológicos não diminui necessariamente a culpa, a vergonha e o estigma percebido, conforme demonstrado por estudos (GOLDSTEIN, ROSSELLI, 2003, NIEUWSMA, PEPPER, 2010). Os resultados aqui encontrados, portanto, destacam a importância de tratamentos não biológicos para os pacientes com TOC, que podem contar com a consagrada terapia de exposição e prevenção de resposta (KOZAK, FOA, et al., 2001), assim como com as novas estratégias que visam potencializar ou redirecionar as intervenções das terapias cognitivo-comportamentais (ABRAMOWITZ, Jonathan S, BLAKEY, et al., 2018). No que diz respeito à percepção de controle, os resultados do presente estudo são consistentes com os achados de Cloitre e colaboradores (1992) que também demonstraram que pacientes com TP referem percepção de controle mais baixa do que pacientes com TAS. O modelo MANCOVA não apontou um papel significativo da sensibilidade à ansiedade nas diferenças entre os grupos no que se refere às crenças de controle dos sintomas. Esses achados estão alinhados com estudos que sugerem que a percepção de controle e a sensibilidade à ansiedade são constructos distintos que contribuem de forma independente no desenvolvimento do TP, apesar de interagirem para produzir sintomas (BENTLEY, GALLAGHER, et al., 2013). Curiosamente, estudos usando a abordagem do lócus de controle mostraram que as crenças no controle pessoal aumentaram a probabilidade de sucesso do tratamento (DUSSELDORP, SPINHOVEN,et al., 2007). Além disso, Bakker e colaboradores (2002) demostraram que o lócus de controle no TP muda com a terapia cognitivo-comportamental (TCC).

Existem algumas limitações a serem consideradas ao interpretar os achados deste estudo. Uma limitação importante é o baixo número de participantes em cada grupo investigado, o que levou a encontrarmos tendências que poderiam ser estatisticamente significativas caso a amostra permitisse maior poder estatístico. Não foi possível recrutar grupos diagnósticos que estivessem completamente livres de outros transtornos ocorrendo concomitantemente, embora as taxas de comorbidade com depressão tenham sido bastante semelhantes nas três subamostras, além da presença de TOC comórbido e transtornos de ansiedade secundários ter sido baixa nos diferentes grupos. Outro fator a considerar é que o recrutamento de participantes atendidos em um hospital psiquiátrico pode ter exercido influência nas características das subamostras. A complexidade das interações e relações causais entre os diferentes sintomas e suas representações cognitivas requer métodos elaborados de análises estatísticas, como análises de rede (HOFMANN, Stefan G, CURTISS, et al., 2016), o que vai além do escopo do presente estudo.

Além disso, argumenta-se que os instrumentos quantitativos são limitados para capturar a natureza dinâmica do MSC e que uma solução possível seriam os métodos mistos que combinassem medidas estáticas de autorrelato com descrições dinâmicas e qualitativas (PHILLIPS, LEVENTHAL, et al., 2017). No entanto, os questionários psicométricos são instrumentos úteis de rastreio dessas variáveis no atendimento clínico de rotina. Para McAndrew e colaboradores (2018), estudos prospectivos podem quantificar melhor os efeitos e a ordem temporal das relações. Leventhal e colaboradores (2016) ressaltam que os processos da percepção da doença se atualizam por meio da ação e da avaliação dos resultados, sendo necessários métodos que se ajustem a esses processos dinâmicos para avaliar as variações intra- individuais, contínua e longitudinalmente. Nesse aspecto, a avaliação ecológica momentânea (AEM) pode ser outra abordagem útil, pois ofereceria uma maneira de avaliar as crenças e comportamentos relacionados à doença em tempo real.

A partir da produção de mais conhecimento nessa área, o trabalho envolvendo as representações da doença na prática clínica pode ser mais precisamente orientado e embasado. Por exemplo, intervenções baseadas em direcionar crenças de controle pessoal e pelo tratamento nos estágios iniciais da TCC promovem melhor engajamento e resultados (MARCUS, GARETY, et al., 2014), enquanto a psicoeducação parece fortalecer as crenças de controle pessoal e na eficácia do tratamento, reduzindo as respostas emocionais negativas sobre o transtorno (ETAIN, Bruno, SCOTT, et al., 2017). Além disso, o insight pode ser um fator que favorece a adesão ao tratamento, a aliança terapêutica e os resultados relacionados à saúde (NOVICK, MONTGOMERY, et al., 2015). Considerado empobrecido em muitos transtornos mentais (AMADOR, FLAUM, et al., 1994, VIGNE, MENEZES, et al., 2014), seria útil incorporar ao MSC aplicado à saúde mental a avaliação do insight sobre a identidade e consequências do problema, por exemplo. Afinal, a combinação da representação da doença com um plano de ação para levar ao autogerenciamento de uma ameaça à saúde faz sentido quando se trata do comportamento de uma pessoa que se percebe doente ou acredita estar lidando com uma ameaça ao seu funcionamento saudável.

Vale lembrar que o MSC é um modelo abrangente de autogestão da saúde explicitamente centrado no paciente e sua cultura, e que supõe serem as representações da doença, altamente individualizadas, os determinantes para o comportamento relacionado à saúde, incluindo o engajamento no tratamento. As representações da doença mental, por exemplo, são preditoras da motivação para a psicoterapia (REICH, BOCKEL, et al., 2015). Além disso, fatores que previram a aceitação de psicoterapias, tais como as expectativas de mudança, a autoeficácia e a concordância entre o modelo causal do paciente e da terapia oferecida, estão vinculados conceitualmente com as dimensões da linha do tempo, controle e atribuições causais, respectivamente (MAVROEIDES, KOUTRA, 2021). Sendo a aliança terapêutica um preditor dos resultados das psicoterapias (FLÜCKIGER, DEL RE, et al., 2012), os profissionais da saúde podem aprimorá-la por meio do conhecimento explícito das representações da doença do paciente, de uma compreensão concordante da ameaça à saúde e da negociação responsiva dos objetivos do tratamento (MCANDREW, MARTIN, et al., 2018). Por exemplo, o desenvolvimento de concordância sobre a percepção de controle (“existem estratégias que você pode aprender para lidar melhor com isso”) e linha do tempo (“provavelmente será necessário usar essas estratégias para o resto da vida”) pode levar à gestão mais efetiva do problema.

Em resumo, este estudo aponta a existência de relações significativas entre sensibilidade à ansiedade, atribuições causais e percepções de controle no TOC, TAS e TP. Estudos futuros são necessários para investigar como as percepções da doença impactam respostas específicas nesses transtornos. Considerar as percepções da doença nas diferentes abordagens de tratamento pode levar a melhores resultados. Embora o presente estudo tenha encontrado um papel potencialmente importante das crenças de controle no TP, deve-se notar que a maioria das diferenças nas representações da doença entre os grupos foram pequenas e não significativas. Este achado corrobora a visão de que diferenças individuais nos aspectos transdiagnósticos podem ser mais relevantes para a eficácia do tratamento do que fatores etiológicos específicos de cada transtorno (ZVOLENSKY, LEVENTHAL, 2016). Por fim, é preciso pressupor a perspectiva do paciente – incluindo suas representações da doença – como válida, para promover avaliações e intervenções idiográficas com orientação biopsicossocial. Na ausência desse conhecimento, propor abordagens terapêuticas específicas pode representar redução de eficácia no tratamento recomendado.
5 CONSIDERAÇÕES FINAIS

O estudo apresentado até aqui é fruto de um trabalho em equipe que permitiu a publicação de quatro artigos (apêndice e anexos a seguir) e a produção de um quinto estudo em fase de finalização, que serão brevemente descritos em uma sequência que conta a história do extensivo trabalho de coleta dados, ampliação da amostra e das análises. O primeiro artigo intitulado “ Duration of untreated illness in a cross-diagnostic sample of obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, and social anxiety disorder” ( ANEXO A) avaliou a duração da doença não tratada em 88 participantes (33 com TOC, 24 com TAS e 31 com TP). O segundo, “Predictors of benzodiazepine use in a transdiagnostic sample of panic disorder, social anxiety disorder, and obsessive-compulsive disorder patients ” (ANEXO B ), avaliou a autoeficácia e as expectativas associadas ao uso de benzodiazepínicos em 102 participantes (38 com TOC, 28 com TAS e 36 com TP). O terceiro artigo (objeto desta dissertação), “ Illness Perceptions Across Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder, and Panic Disorder Patients ” (APÊNDICE A) e o quarto artigo “ The relationship between obsessive-compulsive disorder and anxiety disorders: a question of diagnostic boundaries or simply severity of symptoms?” (ANEXO C ) contaram com a mesma amostra de 108 participantes (38 com TOC, 34 com TAS e 36 com TP). Neste último estudo, categorizando os participantes em subgrupos de sintomas leves, moderados e graves, investigamos como os domínios dos sintomas se agregavam, prevendo que se agrupariam em função da gravidade dos sintomas, de forma menos proeminente conforme a gravidade aumentasse e de maneira independente das categorias diagnósticas do DSM.
5.1 PUBLICAÇÕES E OUTROS ACHADOS

Como acontece em outros transtornos psiquiátricos, a intervenção precoce nos transtornos de ansiedade e no TOC também pode levar a melhores resultados no tratamento. A duração da doença não tratada (do inglês, duration of untreated illness; DUI) pode ser influenciada por fatores não relacionados ao próprio diagnóstico psiquiátrico, incluindo atitudes individuais ou familiares em relação à doença mental (como o estigma), crenças compartilhadas culturalmente (na cura religiosa, por exemplo) e a disponibilidade de sistemas de tratamento para saúde mental. Alguns fatores transdiagnósticos relevantes ainda pouco explorados podem reduzir (por exemplo, sensibilidade à ansiedade) ou retardar (por exemplo, a percepção da doença) o tempo de busca de tratamento, de modo que o medo das sensações físicas de ansiedade pode diminuir esse tempo e a percepção de que o transtorno pode ter causas biológicas ou psicológicas pode determinar se os pacientes irão antecipar ou atrasar a busca por ajuda especializada, independentemente do diagnóstico.

No primeiro artigo (ANEXO A), a amostra foi dividida em DUI curto (<2 anos) e longo (>2 anos) com base na média do número total de participantes. O DUI médio de toda a amostra foi de 7,33 anos e foi significativamente diferente entre os grupos que buscaram tratamento após o início da doença (χ2 = 20,5; df = 2; p <0,001). Os participantes com TOC tiveram um DUI médio mais longo (7,73 [10,51] anos) do que aqueles com TP (1,46 [2,62] anos; χ2 = 8,99; gl = 1; p = 0,003) e mais curto do que aqueles com TAS (13,72 [12,72] anos; χ2 = 4,12; gl = 1; p = 0,04). Após o início da doença, demorou em média 8,44 (11,16) anos para que os pacientes fossem atendidos por um psiquiatra e houve uma tendência de buscar a primeira ajuda de um psicólogo no grupo com TOC. As únicas diferenças entre os grupos foram maior medo de exibição pública dos sintomas de ansiedade no DUI curto (p = 0,03) e maior evitação social no DUI longo (p = 0,03). Observamos que maiores taxas de DUI no TOC (> 2 anos), TAS (> 10 anos) e TP (> 0 anos) não foram relacionadas ao gênero, gravidade dos sintomas nem aos transtornos de humor ou ansiedade comórbidos.

Além disso, a percepção de que o estresse é a causa do TOC foi correlacionada ao DUI mais curto em pacientes com TOC (p = 0,03), ou seja, quanto mais os pacientes com TOC acreditavam que sua doença foi causada por um evento estressor recente (conflito familiar ou conjugal, luto ou separação), mais cedo buscaram tratamento para sua condição. Já a incapacidade relacionada aos sintomas de pânico foi associada ao DUI aumentado em pacientes com TAS (p = 0,01), mas não com TOC ou TP, sugerindo que os ataques de pânico devido ao TAS realmente dificultam a busca de tratamento para esta população. Nenhuma correlação significativa de DUI surgiu na amostra de TP. Além disso, não encontramos nenhuma relação entre sensibilidade à ansiedade e DUI em cada diagnóstico ou em toda a amostra. Maior tempo de DUI foi associado a uma tendência de maiores taxas de transtorno depressivo maior ao longo da vida em pacientes com TAS. Em suma, geralmente havia um atraso substancial na busca de tratamento entre a maioria dos pacientes com TOC e TAS, e a percepção do estresse como causa do TOC motivava a busca mais rápida por tratamento, enquanto a gravidade dos sintomas de pânico em pacientes com TAS atrasou a busca por tratamento.

No estudo realizado no segundo artigo (ANEXO B), previmos que os participantes (particularmente com TP) usassem benzodiazepínicos em taxas consideradas elevadas e por longos períodos, além de que sendo suposto terem níveis mais baixos de autoeficácia (quanto a interromper o uso) e maior sensibilidade à ansiedade, estariam mais propensos ao uso contínuo da medicação. Os grupos diagnósticos eram comparáveis na maioria das características demográficas, porém os participantes com TP desenvolveram seus sintomas mais tarde (F (2,96) = 24,912, p <0,001) e eram tipicamente mais velhos quando vistos pela primeira vez por um psiquiatra (F (2,97) = 8,044, p = 0,001) do que os participantes com TOC (p <0,001 ep = 0,001, respectivamente) e com TAS (p <0,001 ep = 0,02, respectivamente). Em termos de comorbidades, encontramos diferenças significativas nas taxas de distimia ao longo da vida, que eram maiores entre os pacientes com TOC (qui-quadrado = 6,81; df = 2; p = 0,03); agorafobia, que era mais comum entre os pacientes com TP (qui-quadrado = 23,98; df = 2; p <0,001); e dependência de álcool, que foi mais frequentemente relatada no grupo com TAS No momento da avaliação, 55,7% de toda a amostra relatou uso atual de benzodiazepínicos, enquanto 74,5% relataram ter feito uso em algum momento da vida. As taxas de uso atual nas amostras diagnósticas foram de 34,3%, 60,7% e 73,5% para TOC, TAS e TP, respectivamente (qui-quadrado = 11,168; df = 2; p = 0,004), enquanto as taxas de uso ao longo da vida foram de 63,2% em participantes com TOC, 75,0% com TAS e 86,1% com TP (qui-quadrado = 5,13; gl = 2; p = 0,07). Embora 75,4% da amostra atribuiu grande parte de sua melhora aos benzodiazepínicos e 78,9% acreditavam serem necessários como parte de seus tratamentos, 90,9% gostariam de interromper esses medicamentos. Quando questionados sobre os motivos para usar a esta medicação (i) 71,1% indicaram tentar evitar ataques de ansiedade, (ii) 46,1% para dormir melhor ou por causa de insônia, (iii) 38,2% para evitar pensar muito antes de dormir e (iv) 39,5% para se sentir melhor em algumas situações. Em contrapartida, as razões para nunca ter usado esta medicação foram: (i) não ter recebido prescrição de seus médicos em 77,3% dos casos, (ii) medo de se tornar dependente em 27,3%, (iii) uma atitude negativa em relação a tomar medicamentos em geral em 18,2% e (iv) preocupação em ter efeitos colaterais indesejáveis em 9,1%.

Em resumo, os pacientes em uso de benzodiazepínicos eram mais velhos, tinham idade de início do transtorno mais tardia, estavam em tratamento psiquiátrico por períodos mais longos, tiveram maiores índices de ansiedade no BAI (do inglês, Beck Anxiety Inventory) (BECK, EPSTEIN, et al., 1988), de sensibilidade à ansiedade no ASI-R, de agorafobia e comportamentos de evitação no PAS (do inglês, Panic and Agoraphobia Scale) (BANDELOW, 1995), menor autoeficácia em interromper o uso para assistência ao sono de acordo com o BRSEQ (do inglês, Benzodiazepine Refusal Self-Efficacy Questionnaire) (PARR, KAVANAGH, et al., 2009) e aumento das taxas de transtorno depressivo maior ao longo da vida, além de mais comumente o diagnóstico de TP. Em contraste com nossas expectativas, os escores do ASI-R não foram maiores entre os participantes que continuaram ou interromperam o uso dos benzodiazepínicos (p = 0,29). Observamos que a maior duração do tratamento psiquiátrico e a história de TP ao longo da vida (independente do diagnóstico principal no momento da avaliação) foram os fatores preditores de maior influência para o uso de benzodiazepínicos. Devido ao seu rápido efeito ansiolítico, essas drogas são frequentemente usadas como comportamento de segurança, visando a esquiva das intensas reações fisiológicas que os pacientes com transtornos de ansiedade comumente apresentam. Curiosamente, os nossos achados indicaram que os níveis de autoeficácia no que diz respeito a interromper o uso dos benzodiazepínicos e as expectativas de mudança emocional e cognitiva positiva em usá-los foram surpreendentemente altos.

No último artigo publicado (ANEXO C), encontramos evidências que apoiam uma abordagem predominantemente dimensional para o TOC e os transtornos de ansiedade. Conforme previmos, os domínios de sintomas de TOC, TAS e TP não foram mapeados exatamente em suas categorias diagnósticas correspondentes, mas tendiam a se agrupar com base em suas gravidades, com domínios de sintomas mais leves sendo mais propensos a se agruparem. Em particular, uma síndrome “neurótica” leve caracterizada por domínios de sintomas leves, múltiplos, intimamente relacionados e co-ocorrentes, o que pode ser consistente com a ideia de uma via compartilhada precoce prodrômica e ter alguma sobreposição com características como aumento do neuroticismo. Além de refletir o fato de que todos os transtornos de ansiedade (em menor grau o TOC) compartilham perfis de resposta semelhantes seja pelo conjunto de sintomas (medos proeminentes e comportamentos evitativos) ou pelas mesmas estratégias de tratamento (inibidores de recaptação de serotonina e terapias de exposição). Subsequentemente, duas síndromes “neuróticas” moderadas, complicada e não complicada, sendo a primeira associada ao TP e ao aumento da incapacidade, são o reflexo de um espectro de gravidade dos domínios dos sintomas onde o distanciamento um do outro atinge sua expressão máxima no grupo de sintomas “neuróticos” graves e dispersos. Aparentemente, à medida que a gravidade do TOC e dos sintomas dos transtornos de ansiedade aumentam, eles tendem a se apresentar como fenômenos clínicos proeminentemente isolados. Nossos resultados sugerem que os domínios dos sintomas de pacientes com TOC, TAS e TP tendem a ser mais bem conceitualizados em termos de gravidade, em vez de limites diagnósticos rígidos. No que diz respeito as estratégias de regulação emocional, não está claro se os transtornos de ansiedade diferem entre si. Prevendo que há diferenças, avaliamos a flexibilidade psicológica e os estilos afetivos de 32 participantes com TOC, 30 com TAS, 30 com TP, além de 21 participantes saudáveis, através do Questionário de Aceitação e Ação (AAQ II, do inglês Acceptance and Action Questionnaire II) (BOND, HAYES, et al., 2011) e do Questionário de Estilos Afetivos (ASQ, do inglês Affective Style Questionnaire) (HOFMANN, Stefan, KASHDAN, 2010). O ASQ é composto por 3 subescalas que medem diferentes estilos afetivos: supressão (tentativas de ocultar ou suprimir emoções), ajustamento (capacidade de ajustar e gerenciar as emoções) e tolerância (aceitação e/ou tolerância em relação às emoções). A gravidade dos sintomas foi avaliada em toda a amostra (111) através do DOCS (do inglês, Dimensional Obsessive-Compulsive Scale) (ABRAMOWITZ, Jonathan, DEACON, et al., 2010), do SPIN (do inglês, Social Phobia Inventory) (CONNOR, DAVIDSON, et al., 2000), do PAS (BANDELOW, 1995) e das Escalas de Ansiedade (BAI) e Depressão de Beck (BDI, do inglês Beck Depression Inventory) (BECK, EPSTEIN, et al., 1988; BECK, WARD, et al., 1961). Nesse estudo, hipotetizamos que os estilos afetivos seriam diferentes entre as amostras. Mais especificamente, que os participantes com TAS serão mais propensos a suprimir suas emoções, que os participantes com TP serão menos tolerantes às emoções e que aqueles com TOC serão menos propensos a ajustar suas emoções (maior rigidez). Resultados preliminares revelaram uma diferença entre os grupos diagnósticos em seus estilos afetivos e/ou esquiva experiencial [F (12, 290) = 1,88, p = 0,036] e uma diferença significativa entre os grupos nos escores do ASQ-T (subescala de tolerância) [F (3,109) = 4,50, p = 0,005].
6 MEMORIAL DA TRAJETÓRIA ACADÊMICA

Fontenelle1,3,4 #International Association of Cognitive Psychotherapy 2018 Abstract We investigated whether panic disorder (PD), obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), andsocial anxiety disorder (SAD) patients differ in the perception of their illnesses andwhether these differences can be ascribed to levels of anxiety sensitivity. We performeda cross-sectional study comparing responses from 36 PD patients, 38 OCD, and 34 SADpatients in the Illness Perception Questionnaire-Mental Health (IPQ-MH). A MANCOV Amodel with the diagnostic group as the fixed factor, the IPQ-MH items as dependent variables, and the Anxiety Sensitivity Index-Revised (ASI-R) score as a covariate, was created. Significant differences were observed between the groups with respect to illnessperception. PD patients showed significantly higher levels of anxiety sensitivity than othergroups. However, after controlling for anxiety sensitivity as a covariate, patients with PDhad significant lower scores in“personal control”and“treatment control”than patients with SAD. OCD patients did not differ significantly from both groups. PD, OCD, andSAD patients have both common and different perceptions regarding their illnesses.Differences between PD and SAD are related to controllability of symptoms, but seem not to be mediated by anxiety sensitivity. Future studies should investigate whether illness perceptions in OCD and anxiety disorders have therapeutic implications.

According to the SRM, the possible variables within each of these domains, the procedures for threat management, and the variability of appraisals of their responses will shape how individuals cope with their illness. Although the responses of individuals with physical conditions (Hagger and Orbell 2003 ) to the Illness Perception Questionnaire (IPQ) (Weinman et al. 1996 ) have bee n the main focus of research in SRM area, growing interest in individuals ’perception of their own mental health problems have lead to adaptations of the IPQ for a wide rangeof psychiatric disorders (Baines and Wittkowski 2013 ; Chan and Mak 2016 ), including psy chotic disorders (Freeman et al. 2013 ), depression (Lynch et al. 2015 ), and obsessive- com pulsive disorder (OCD) (Fernandez de la Cruz et al. 2016 ).

Only very few studies investigated patient ’s beliefs about the causes of OCD and anxiety disorders. Interestingly, most studies in anxiety disorders have addressed howillness perceptions influence treatment preferences, expectations, and responses (Cohenet al. 2015 ; Johnson et al. 2000 ; Lam and Salkovskis 2007 ; Waikar et al. 1994 ). Howe ver, perhaps because samples were heterogeneous, no consistent pattern emerged in these studies. Further, research on illness perception in OCD samples is even sparser.For instance, rather than addressing self-perception, existing OCD studies have inves-tigated the general population perception of OCD using qualitative interviews (Pedleyet al. 2017 ) or adapted versions of existing quantitative instruments (Fernandez de la Cruz et al. 2016 ). Thus, there are no studies using reliable psychometric instruments to comp are illness perception of patients with anxiety disorders and OCD patients.

The representation of anxiety and its meaning is strongly influenced by somatic symptoms of arousal. One potential dimension that has been suggested to explainindividual differences in the development of anxiety disorders and OCD is anxietysensitivity, which refers the fear of anxiety-related bodily sensations (Reiss et al.1986 ). Anxiety sensitivity is based on the person ’s beliefs that anxiety symptoms ha ve harmful physical (fear of somatic symptoms), psychological (fear of cognitive dyscontrol), or social consequences (fear of publicly observable anxiety symptoms)(Reiss 1991 ). Although originally described as an important factor in the etiology of PD , research has also implicated anxiety sensitivity in the origins and maintenance of other disorders (Olatunji and Wolitzky-Taylor 2009 ), such as SAD (Alkozei et al. 2015 ) and OCD (Laposa et al. 2015 ). Thus, anxiety sensitivity may be an important de terminant of illness perceptions, affecting several aspects of the self-regulation and consequently, the perceptions of mental health problems.

The primary goal of our study was to compare and analyze different aspects of illness perceptions across three mental disorders, i.e., OCD, SAD, and PD, byusing the IPQ adapted for Mental Health [IPQ-MH] (Witteman et al. 2011 ). The fo llowing predictions were tested. Firstly, we predicted that groups would differ in terms of illness perceptions of causes of their illnesses. For instance, given thewidespread popularity of the“chemical imbalance”mod el of OCD (Stahl 1988 ), we expected OCD patients to more frequently attribute their illness to genetic and/ or biological causes than PD and SAD patients, which in turn would be morelikely to ascribe their problems to stress and psychological causes, respectively. Secondly, we hypothesized that, as compared to both OCD and SAD patients, PDInternational Journal of Cognitive Therapy patients would perceive their illnesses as less under their personal control but as more under treatment control. Thirdly, we predicted significant group differencesin anxiety sensitivity, with PD patients showing higher levels than the othergroups. As subjects showing high anxiety sensitivity tend not recognize thecatastrophic nature of their thoughts, it seems likely that individuals with highanxiety sensitivity would perceive their symptoms as less under their personal and/or treatment control. Thus, we also investigated whether any differences in illness representations would remain when controlling for anxiety sensitivity. Inclusion criteria we re as follows: (i) a primary diagnosis of OCD, SAD or PD; (ii) age between 18 and 70 years; and (iii) being able to read and fill out forms. The Anxiety Sensitivity Index-Revised (ASI-R) is a self-report 36-item question- naire that quantifies anxiety sensitivity, i.e., the fear of anxiety-related bodily sensations(Taylor and Cox 1998 ). The ASI-R is the only valid instrument to assess anxiety sens itivity in Brazilian Portuguese. Anxiety sensitivity results from a series of beliefs that anxiety symptoms can have harmful physical, psychological or social conse-quences (Reiss 1991 ), e.g., “When I feel like I ’m not getting enough air I get scared that I might suffocate ”(Taylor and Cox 1998 ). The ASI-R is a revised and expanded vers ion of the original 16-item Anxiety Sensitivity Index (Reiss et al. 1986 ), whose brev ity was felt to restrict the number of low-order factors associated with the anxiety sensitivity construct. The ASI-R was selected to assess fear of harmful physical,psychological, or social consequences of anxiety-related bodily sensations. It consists of 36 items that measure (a) cardiovascular fears, (b) respiratory fears, (c) gastrointes- tinal symptoms and fears, (d) fear of cognitive dyscontrol, (e) fear of publicly observ-able anxiety reactions, and (f) neurological and dissociative symptoms. Each item israted on a 5-point Likert scale with varied from 0 (very little) to 4 (very much). Thevalidity and reliability of the 36-item measure have been confirmed in many studies(Olatunji and Wolitzky-Taylor 2009 ). Discussion The assessment of individual perceptions of anxiety disorders is an importantprerequisite in the development of more personalized and effective treatments. Inaddition to qualitative methods, psychometric questionnaires are useful instru-ments for screening in routine clinical care. The present study is the first to allowsystematic comparisons in terms of illness perception between PD, OCD, andSAD using a standardized questionnaire. While groups did not differ in terms ofperceived duration, cyclic regularity, consequences, coherence, and associatedemotions of the illnesses, PD patients believed stress to be a cause of their mental health problem and perceived their illness as less controllable both by personal and well as by therapeutic means than the other groups.

The fact that PD patients ascribed their illness to stress more often than SAD is consistent with previous studies linking stress to PD (Albert et al. 2005 ; Faravelli 1985 ; Far avelli and Pallanti 1989 ; Manfro et al. 1996 ; Moitra et al. 2011 ; Roy-Byrne et al. 1986 ; Scocco et al. 2007 ). Importantly, we found that perception of stress as a cause of PD was partially dependent on the levels of anxiety sensitivity. Schmidt et al. ( 1997 , 1999 ) found increased anxiety sensitivity to predict panic attacks in subjects undergo- ing stressful military training. However, given our cross-sectional design, it is impos- sible to determine at this point whether increased stress leads to increased anxietysensitivity or vice-versa (Schmidt et al. 2000 ). There are reasons to suspect that anxiety sens itivity primes individuals to the effects of stress, though (Klauke et al. 2010 ). Secondly, it also appears that increased anxiety sensitivity confers increased vulnerability for the development of PD (Calkins et al. 2009 ).

Thir dly, a role for stress in preceptating panic disorders in susceptible individuals has been suggested by different studies. Although it is beyond the scope of the presentstudy to review this literature, a recent study found separation/loss events to beassociated more strongly with panic pathology among individuals with higher child-hood adversities (Asselmann et al. 2018 ). In li ne with previous studies on traumatic events, OCD and SAD subjects did not differ in terms of perception of stress as cause of their illness (Fontenelle et al. 2007 ). Howe ver, in contrast to our predictions, OCD patients did not more frequently attribute their problem to biological causes. Previous studies showed that the attribution of mental disorders’etiology to biological factors do not necessarily decrease self-blame and perceived stigma nor increases emporwerment as previously thought (Goldstein and Rosselli 2003 ; Nieuwsma and Pepper 2010 ). Our findings highlight the importance of non-biolog ical (e.g., lifestyle) anti-OCD treatments, which may be potentially acceptable for OCD patients.

Our results are also consistent with the findings by Cloitre et al. ( 1992 ) who also found PD to show lower controllability levels than SAD. Further, our MANCOV A model did not support a significant role of anxiety sensitivity into the differences in terms of beliefs into controllability of symptoms across disorders. These findings are consistent with studies suggesting that perception of control and anxiety sensitivity are distinct constructsthat contribute independently to panic disorder pathology despite interacting synergisti-cally to produce panic symptoms (Bentley et al. 2013 ). Interestingly, studies using the lo cus of control approach showed that beliefs in personal controllability increased the probability of treatment success (Dusseldorp et al. 2007 ). In addition, Bakker et al. ( 2002 ) sho wed locus of control in PD to change with cognitive-behavioral therapy.

There are several limitations to consider when interpreting our findings. An essential limitation is the cross-sectional design of our study, which does not allow for anyconlusions regarding the causal roles of illness representations and symptoms of anxietydisorders. Furthermore, we were unable to recruit diagnostic groups that were completelyfree of co-occurring disorders, although the comorbidity rates with depression were quitesimilar across the three subsamples and presence of secondary anxiety disorders or OCDwas low. The complexity of interactions and causal relationships between differentsymptoms and their cognitive representations requires elaborate methods of statisticalanalyses such as network analyses (Hofmann et al. 2016 ), which goes beyond the scope of the present study. Also, the recruitment of participants from a psychiatric hospital may have exerted a differential influence on the characteristics of the subsamples. In sum, our study supports the existence of significant relationships between anxiety sensitivity, perception of causes, and control beliefs in OCD, SAD and PD. Addressingillness perceptions in treatment approaches may provide improved outcomes. Futurestudies may investigate how illness perceptions impact specific responses across OCD,SAD and PD. Apart from the important role of controllability beliefs in PD, however, itshould be noted that most differences in illness representations were small and nonsig- nificant. This finding supports the view that individual differences in transdiagnosticInternational Journal of Cognitive Therapy factors may be more relevant for treatment effectiveness than disorder-specific etiolog- ical factors (Zvolensky and Leventhal 2016 ).

In this study, we compared duration of untreated illness (DUI) in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), panic disorder (PD), and social anxiety disorder (SAD) patients and investigated its correlates, both within specific diagnoses and across the whole sample.

Methods. Eighty-eight patients (33 OCD, 24 SAD, and 31 PD) had their diagnosis confirmed by the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview, were assessed for treatment-seeking variables, and were evaluated with instruments aimed at quantifying transdiagnostic features (i.e., the Cause subscale of the Illness Perception Questionnaire–Mental Health and the Anxiety Sensitivity Index–Revised) and severity of illness (i.e., Beck Depression and Anxiety Inventories, the Dimensional Obsessive-Compulsive Scale, the Panic and Agoraphobia Scale, and the Social Phobia Inventory). Results. The only differences between groups with short (<2 years) versus long (>2 years) DUI were greater fear of public display of anxiety in the first group and greater social avoidance in the second group. The DUI was significantly different between groups that sought treatment after the onset of illness, with OCD patients having longer DUI thanPD patients and shorter DUI than SAD patients. Further, DUI correlated negatively with the perception of OCD being caused by stress and positively with severity of panic-related disability in SAD patients, but not in PD or OCD patients. Conclusion. There was substantial delay in treatment seeking among the anxiety and obsessive-compulsive disorder patients, particularly those with OCD or SAD. Perception of stress as a cause of OCD prompted treatment seeking, while severity of panic symptoms delayed treatment seeking.

Clearly, DUI may be influenced by factors unrelated to the psychiatric diagnosis itself, including individual or family attitudes toward mental illness (such as fear ofstigma), cultural beliefs (e.g., in religious or traditionalhealing), and the availability of mental health-caresystems (which, once engaged, should be able to provideassessment in a timely fashion).
2However, we believe

that a few relevant cross-diagnostic features that have notbeen explored yet in relation to DUI may also reduce(e.g., anxiety sensitivity 12) or retard (e.g., illness percep- tion13) time to treatment seeking. For instance, we hypothesize that not only does the fear caused by anxiety-related symptoms (e.g., rapid heartbeat) actually shortentime to treatment seeking regardless of diagnosis, butalso the perception of the certain causes of the AOCD(e.g., the lack of supportive communities) may deter-mine whether patients will anticipate or delay treatmentseeking. The use of DUI in the context of AOCD should take into consideration some particularities of the latterconditions, including the meaning of“onset”and“adequate treatment.”For instance, onset of illness is more often insidious in AOCD than in acute psychosis, and adequate treatment in AOCD often includes non-pharmacologic approaches, such as exposure andresponse prevention in OCD

Greater DUIs in OCD ( >2 years), SAD ( >10 years), and PD (>0 years), defined as DUI greater than the median values within a specific group, were unrelated to genderand most comorbid mood or anxiety disorders. However, greater DUI was associated on a trend level with greater lifetime rates of major depressive disorder in SADpatients. This finding is consistent with studies showingpatients with SAD to be at an increased risk fordepression

However,due to our cross-sectional design, we were unable todetermine if untreated SAD contributed to increased rates of depression or depression decreased treatment seeking, thus increasing DUI. A previous study found DUI in PD tobe associated with a higher frequency of depression. Further, DUI correlated negatively with the percep- tion of OCD being caused by stress. In other words, themore patients with OCD believed that their illness wascaused by the threat of or an actual recent veryunpleasant event, family or marital conflict or difficulty,grief or separation, or even physical illness, the soonerOCD patients sought treatment for their condition. Wecan only speculate about why the perceived etiologicalrole of stress was restricted to the OCD sample. Forinstance, while OCD patients may perceive distress(including actual marital or family dysfunction 26) as a proxy for greater severity of OCD symptoms, they may also believe that stress-related problems are more readily treatable by a mental health specialist.

We also found a positive correlation between DUI and severity of panic-related disability in SAD, but not inOCD or PD patients, thus suggesting that panic attacksdue to SAD actually hinder treatment seeking in thislater population. It may be, for instance, that theanticipation of potential scrutiny by mental health specialists, often qualified as“authority figures,”actually leads SAD patients who are already housebound anddisabled by“situational”panic attacks to delay or avoidappropriate treatment.
27Although we have hypothesized

28severities of panic attacks in PD did not correlate

A trend toward seeking first help from a psychologist was reported in the OCD group as compared with PD or SAD groups. This finding is consistent with the increas-ing popularity of psychological treatments, particularlyexposure and response prevention (ERP), for OCDpatients. In contrast, the hint toward decreased psycho-logical treatment for other conditions may also reflect a predominant fear of somatic (medical) illnesses among PD patients and of having intimate issues“fleshed out”and scrutinized during psychological assessments amongSAD patients; theoretically, in these cases, patients couldbe inclined to“bypass”initial assessments by psycholo-gists. However, this phenomenon may also be ascribed toa proclivity of psychotherapists not to refer PD and SADpatients to psychiatric assessment. Our paper has a number of limitations that limit its comparability with previous studies. Most strikingly, weemployed a definition of DUI that emphasized“anymental health treatment”instead of“appropriate phar-macologic treatment,”which probably has a“psychiatric” bias.

1. Introduction

There is an ongoing controversy about the use of benzodiazepines (BZD) in the treatment of anxiety disorders (AD). Although BZD use in routine care is supported by a large body of research, problems related to BZDs use have been largely documented, including increased risks of psychological dependence (e.g. in up to 60.8% of panic disorder [PD] patients) ( Fujii et al., 2015), deliberate self-poisoning (particularly in patients taking higher average cumulative doses) ( Shih et al., 2013 ), cognitive impairment, dementia, delirium, falls, fractures, and motor vehicle crashes in older adults (2015; Pariente et al., 2016 ), and in- creased resistance to antidepressant treatment in major depression patients ( Parker and Graham, 2015 ). It has also been suggested that as needed ”) use of BZDS in the context of PD may lead to aggravation of panic symptoms ( Westra and Stewart, 2002; Westra et al., 2002), as BZDS may decrease the individual tolerance to anxiety and discomfort (Fava et al., 1994) and interfere with fear extinction (Hart et al., 2014 ). In fact, although several guidelines for BZD use have now been published, the majority of clinicians/patients ignore theirrecommendations and most BZD users (up to 82.5%) exceed the dura- tion of“safe use”( Manthey et al., 2011b ). Inappropriate use has been independently associated with older age and the presence of chronic illnesses ( Manthey et al., 2011b).

However, it would also be probably naïve to ignore the qualities of BZDs, particularly in the treatment of ADs ( Fava et al., 2015; Starcevic, Firstly, BZDs are quite eﬀ ective. A meta-analysis of treatments for PD, generalized anxiety disorder [GAD], and social phobia found BZDs to be associated with high eﬀ ect sizes (Cohen's d = 2.15) ( Bandelow et al., 2015b). Further, at least two systematic reviews found BDZs to lead to comparable or greater improvements and fewer adverse events than newer antidepressants in the treatment of PD andGAD patients ( Berney et al., 2008; O ﬃdani et al., 2013 ). Secondly, follow-up studies of BZD use in anxious patients showed not only eﬃ- cacy ( Davidson et al., 1991 ), but also dose stability ( Mueller et al., 2005 ) and less relapse as compared to antidepressants ( Freire et al., 2017 ). Thirdly, once though to be prohibitive among AD patients with substance abuse, use of BZDs does not appear to induce relapse or de novo alcohol abuse ( Mueller et al., 2005; Posternak and Mueller, 2001 ). Finally, although the concomitant use of BZDs and CBT has been dis- couraged, a systematic review found no good quality research sup- porting the detrimental eﬀect of BZDs on the therapeutic eﬃcacy of CBT in PD patients ( Watanabe et al., 2007).

Given the conﬂicting evidence supporting the prescription of BZDs to AD patients, it has not been easy to decide whether, when and how to use BZDs in such cases. Recent pharmacotherapeutic guidelines on the treatment of PD and social anxiety disorder (SAD) patients have in- cluded BZDs as second-line treatments that should be only prescribed for short-periods ( Baldwin et al., 2014; Bandelow et al., 2015a, 2012, 2015; Katzman et al., 2014; NICE, 2014 ); some guidelines have even advised against its prescriptions ( Bandelow et al., 2015a; ). As BZD use may be related to a series of adverse outcomes, it is important to identify factors associated with increased BZD use. After a 2 years follow- up, continued BZD use (in 54.2% of the sample) was predicted by higher age, severe anxiety, and a long duration of BZD use ( Manthey et al., However, little is known about psychological factors that inﬂ uence the continuation of BZD use. Bandura's concept of self-eﬃcacy (i.e. someone's belief in his/her own ability to succeed in speci ﬁc situations or to accomplish a task) ( Bandura, 1997) has been employed to describe the beliefs/cognitions of chronic BZD users ( Parr et al., 2009; Ten Wolde et al., 2008). Accordingly, Ten Wolde and colleagues in- vestigated whether social and cognitive factors could predict planned and actual cessation of continued BZD use in a nine-month follow-up study of chronic BZD users ( Ten Wolde et al., 2008 ). They found that withdrawal or reduction of BZD intake were predicted by positive ex- pectations and outcomes of quitting, expectations of less negative long- term outcomes, increased self-eﬃcacy about quitting, lower agreement with the disengagement beliefs (i.e.“justiﬁcations aimed at lowering perceived health threats”) and a more positive intention to quit ( Ten Wolde et al., 2008 ). Eventually, Parr and colleagues ( Parr et al., 2009 ) developed two self-report questionnaires that assess self-e ﬃcacy and expectancy associated with BZD use. They found signiﬁcant correla- tions of low self-eﬃcacy and high expectancy with severity of BZD dependence.

In addition to cognitive factors related to expectation, self-eﬃcacy, and intention, motivation for BZD use and cessation may also be modiﬁed by speciﬁc symptoms of ADs or OCD. For instance, reactions to withdrawal symptoms may diﬀer between ADs ( Lader and Kyriacou, 2016 ). In addition, due to their potent physiological eﬀ ects, BZDs are often used as a safety-seeking behaviors aiming at the prevention of catastrophic physiological reactions that AD patients frequently show.Also, in patients with fear of physiological arousal, the withdrawal of BZDs may be perceived as threatening, especially in PD ( Salkovskis, 2009; Thwaites and Freeston, 2005 ) and SAD ( Wells et al., 1995 ) pa- tients, but probably less so in OCD patients ( Deacon and Maack, 2008 ).

Finally, the so-called anxiety sensitivity, i.e. the fear of the experience of physical, psychological and social consequences of anxiety, may be an additional barrier preventing AD patients to cease BZD use ( Reiss, 1991 ). Indeed, anxiety sensitivity is actually an important factor in the development and maintenance of AD symptoms ( Olatunji and Wolitzky- Taylor, 2009 ), particularly PD ( Reiss, 1991 ), but also OCD ( Laposa et al., 2015) and SAD ( Alkozei et al., 2014).

In this study, our objectives were three fold. Firstly, we wanted todetermine the rates of current and past BZD use in public ADs clinicsspecialized in the pharmacological treatment of PD, SAD and OCD. We expected individuals attending these clinics (particularly PD patients) to use BZDs at increased rates, often on a long-term basis, and to show low-self eﬃcacy levels. Secondly, we wanted to investigate which socio demographic and/or clinical factors determined the use of BZDs using the whole ADs sample, including diagnostic (DSM) categories and “transdiagnostic ”(e.g. anxiety sensitivity) traits. Because lower per- ceived support, maladaptive coping strategies, and greater emotionalarousal have been reported in older individuals using BZD ( Pérodeau and Cappeliez, 2007), we predicted that a group of older and more physically and psychosocially vulnerable individuals would be also particularly prone to be on BZDs ( Manthey et al., 2011b). Lastly, we were interested in studying the psychological factors that were asso- ciated with continuation vs. discontinuation of BZD use, both within thewhole research group and in each diagnostic category. We predicted that more vulnerable individuals, with lower levels of self-e ﬃcacy ( Parr et al., 2009 ) and greater anxiety sensitivity (fear of anxiety related symptoms) ( Taylor and Cox, 1998 ) would be particularly prone to continued BZD
2. Methods

One hundred sixteen consecutive patients who sought treatment at one of three ADs clinics specialized in PD, SAD, and OCD, all located within the Institute of Psychiatry of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (IPUB/UFRJ), were assessed for inclusion in this research protocol. Inclusion criteria comprised (i) having PD, SAD, or OCD as the main psychiatric condition, described by the attending physician as the one associated with greater severity of symptoms as compared to other comorbid conditions, (ii) being aged between 18 and 70 years-old, and(iii) being able to read andﬁll out forms. In contrast, patients were excluded if they had serious psychiatric conditions that compromised the interpretation or completion of the scales (e.g. mental retardation, manic episode, psychotic episode or dementia) and severe personality disorders (judged to be present by the attending physician).
2.1. Subjects

Fourteen subjects were preliminary excluded from our study for not meeting inclusion criteria, i.e. two subjects were excluded for being over 70 years old, three volunteers did not have a main diagnosis of PD, SAD, and OCD, and nine subjects did not complete the evaluation in- struments to acceptable levels. Eventually, 102 subjects were eligible and included the study, 36 in the PD group, 28 in the SAD group and 38 in the OCD group. The content and the procedures involved in this research protocol were explained to all participants, who also signed an informed consent before being formally assessed. Categorical variables were described in frequencies and percen- tages, while continuous variables were portrayed in terms of means andstandard deviations. For comparisons between three groups (OCD, SAD and PD), we employed chi-square for categorical variables and one-way analysis of variance followed by post-hoc Tukey's test or for continuous variables. For comparisons between two groups, we employed chi- square test for categorical variables and Student's t or Mann-Whitney test for continuous variables. 4. Discussion

In this cross-sectional observational study, we found BZDs to be frequently prescribed to patients attending an ADs clinic (55.7%), often on a long-term basis (95.8% for at least 6 continuous months). We have also noted that the duration of psychiatric treatment and a lifetime history of PD (regardless of the main diagnosis presented by the pa- tients attending the clinic) were independent risk factors for current BZD prescription. Self-eﬃcacy levels in terms of BZD use and ex- pectancy of positive emotional and cognitive change due to BZDs were surprisingly high. Finally, patients who continued to use BZDs diﬀered from patients who stopped them by being older (both currently and whenﬁrstly seen in the clinic), by having a later age at onset of their most signiﬁcant AD, by being more agoraphobic/avoidant, and by be- lieving to be less capable of stopping their BZDs for the fear of not being able to sleep.

The rates of current (55.7%) and lifetime use of BZDs (74.5%) among our patients were quite high, being greater in PD and lower in OCD subjects, similarly to what has been found in a North American treatment-seeking sample ( Sorsdahl et al., 2013 ). In addition, most of our patients used BZDs on a long-term basis. These ﬁndings are con- sistent with data from a naturalistic multisite follow-up study that re-ported rates of BZD use to be 63.8% among PD ( Bruce et al., 2003 ), 56% among SAD (Vasile et al., 2005), and 61% among GAD ( Vasile et al., 2005 ) patients. Of note, these rates tended to be relatively stable over time, with non-signi ﬁcant decreases. Even among older (> 55 and < 70 years) subjects, the rates of BZD use did not change much, i.e. from 53% at baseline to 41% by the end of 9 years ( Benitez et al., 2008 ).Importantly, this relative stability took place in the presence of heavy SSRI and venlafaxine marketing and corresponding changes in ther-apeutic guidelines ( Benitez et al., 2008; Bruce et al., 2003; Vasile et al., 2005 ). Other studies found signi ﬁcant increases in antidepressant use paralleled by a trend towards decreased BZD use ( Olfson et al., 2004).

Although not oﬃcially recommended as a treatment for OCD in most treatment guidelines ( Baldwin et al., 2014; Bandelow et al., BZDs were being taken by 34.3% of our OCD patients at the time of their assessment, consistently with reports from the US [35.5% ( Blanco et al., 2006 ) to 37.8% ( Sorsdahl et al., 2013)], but also substantially higher than most specialized centers in the world (10.1% in South Africa to 28.3% in India) ( Brakoulias et al., 2016). Predictably, our rates are also similar to the ones reported by an independent and ex- panded sample of almost one thousand OCD patients from the Brazilian Research Consortium for Obsessive-Compulsive Spectrum Disorders (41.1%) ( Brakoulias et al., 2016 ). Increased rates of BZD use by our OCD patients may have resulted from increased comorbidity with other ADs that may be treatable with BZDs themselves ( Brakoulias et al., 2016 ) and to the fact that research groups within our clinic often refer patients to one another. One study found BZD use in OCD patients to be associated with higher age, anxiety levels and number of additional medications for OCD taken over time ( Starcevic et al., 2016 ). Results of our univariate analysis showed patients on BZDs to dis- play a diﬀ erent sociodemographic proﬁle, including greater age and a later onset of disorder. While being older dovetails with our predictions(Demyttenaere et al., 2008; Manthey et al., 2011b ), late onset of symptoms may coincide with a decrease of social support that com- monly occurs later in life. It is diﬃ cult to establish, though, whether greater anxiety, anxiety sensitivity, and severity of PD symptoms andincreased lifetime rates of major depression are causes of greater pre- scriptions/increased use of BZDs or actually detrimental consequences of BZDs, which may interfere negatively with fear extinction ( Fava et al., 1994; Hart et al., 2014). It is also interesting to note that, despite being prescribed at greater rates from many specialized centers worldwide, BZD use within our sample was negatively associated with adiagnosis of OCD, thus suggesting that clinicians are more parsimonious when prescribing BZDs to OCD patients as compared to PD or SAD patients. Importantly, our BZD users were also under psychiatric treatment for longer periods.

In contrast, our multivariate analysis showed that the duration of psychiatric treatment and a lifetime history of PD (regardless of the main diagnosis) were the only independent risk factors for current BZD prescription. However, for being cross-sectional, our study doesn’t allow us to establish causative relationships between BZDs and treat- ment duration. Whether this phenom- enon translates into better outcomes can only be answered by pro- spective studies, though. Alternatively, ourﬁndings may be interpreted as evidence that BZDs are prescribed mostly for patients who have been under treatment for longer periods. Nevertheless, we doubt that this is the case, as psychiatrists are generally mindful about the consequences of prescription of BZDs to older patients ( Olfson et al., 2015 ). The fact that PD, and not severity of PD symptoms, predicted cur- rent BZD use suggests that clinicians tend to reserve these drugs for the typical PD patient, particularly those that are distressed or dysfunc- tional enough to fulﬁll DSM criteria. Likewise, it also seems to imply that BZDs are not prescribed or are actually precluded when panic and agoraphobic symptoms result from other conditions (e.g. OCD and SAD). While this approach indicates that clinicians are restrictive in their approach to drug treatment of ADs, it also indicates that they tend not to think transdiagnostically when it comes to prescription of BZDs. Whereas BZDs have been shown to be eﬀective in DSM deﬁned PD (Davidson, 1997) and SAD ( Davidson et al., 1993; Pollack et al., 2014; Versiani et al., 1997), its controversial utility in OCD samples ( Crockett et al., 2004; Hewlett et al., 1992; Hollander et al., 2003) may partially explain these ﬁndings.

Finally, we have also investigated how AD patients who are still using BZDs diﬀ ered from other patients who have stopped taking these drugs. We interpret our ﬁndings regarding the whole AD sample as indicating that continued use of BZDs might be determined by an “avoidant style ”of dealing with distress that may characterize the so- called “vulnerable” individuals. In contrast, we believe that the most notable result regarding an speciﬁc AD was found in OCD patients who remained on BZDs, i.e. not only they showed lower levels of self-eﬃ- cacy due to sleep problem concerns, but they also were more depressed and avoidant and also displayed more severe unacceptable thoughts than their counterparts who had stopped their BZDs. Continued BZDuse may help alleviating depression, avoidant behaviors and or sexual/ religious thoughts of OCD patients or discontinuation of BZDs actually lead to withdrawal-like depression, avoidant or OCD symptoms, as previously reported ( Cardoso and Vargas, 1996; Drummond and Matthews, 1988; Matthews and Drummond, 1987). Alternatively, this particular OCD phenotype may be more vulnerable to the unfavorable eﬀects of BZD use, for its greater interference with fear extinctionmechanisms ( Hart et al., 2014 ). Besides being a cross-sectional study with small sample sizes, our study suﬀer from other signi ﬁcant limitations. Firstly, it doesn ’t allow us to disentangle the act of prescribing BZDs by the attending psy-chiatrist from the act of taking the BZD by the patients. In other words, readers should borne in mind that patients can either continue to have or interrupt BZD use in clear disagreement with medical advice, a fact that may limit our interpretation of “BZDs use ”as corresponding in- tegrally to the prescription of BZDs by the attending physician.Secondly, increased rates of BZD prescription within our clinic may have resulted from “a carry on ”eﬀect, i.e. ADs patients may simply remain on drugs have been prescribed outside of our center, often a“knee-jerk ”reaction by busy primary care physicians or other non psychiatrists facing anxious or “neurotic ”patients ( Alvarenga et al., 2008; Brunoni et al., 2013; Kapczinski et al., 2001; Quintana et al., Further, someone could argue that our ﬁndings are not completely reliable, as BZD prescription may reﬂ ect diﬀerent treatment practices by diﬀerent doctors in di ﬀerent clinics. However, attending physicians from our clinics have similar levels of training and are supervised byclinicians who had similar academic background themselves (de Menezes, Freire, and Fontenelle). Finally, there is evidence that the continuous usage of BZDs may be contingent on other factors that were not addressed by our study, such as their availability by health systems/ insurance plans, BZD pills supply ( Bushnell et al., 2017), and ﬁrst prescription of long-acting BZDs ( Bushnell et al., 2017). For instance, anincrease in the use of BZD by older patients with ADs has been seen between 2004 and 2009 in US, partly due to insurance coverage changes ( Wu et al., 2013). However, by having all these factors under controlled conditions, our study would probably loose its naturalistic fashion.

To wrap up, we conclude prescriptions of BZDs (i) to be commonly provided to AD patients attending a specialized tertiary clinic; (ii) to be strongly associated with duration of psychiatric treatment and a life- time history of PD; (iii) to be related to higher self-eﬃ cacy levels and greater expectancy of positive emotional and cognitive change thaninitially hypothesized; and (iv) to be more likely to be discontinued by younger, early onset AD patients, specially those that are less concerned about not being able to sleep in case BZDs use are interrupted. Although the tolerability of BZDs has been continuously questioned (e.g. see 2015 Updated Beers Criteria for Potentially Inappropriate Medication Use in Older Adults) ( AGS_2015_Beers_Criteria_Update_Expert_Panel, 2015 ), we believe that its frequency of use justiﬁ es further study of its eﬃ cacy and tolerability, particularly in patients with severe and/or treatment resistant ADs. 1. Introduction

Despite being listed in different chapters of DSM5 [i.e. obsessive- compulsive and related disorders (OCRDs) and anxiety disorders], obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), social anxiety disorder (SAD) and panic disorder (PD) are closely related to each other, as shown byshared symptoms (e.g. prominent fears and avoidant behaviors) [ 1], co-occurrence [ 2], common genetic factors [ 3,4], increased family ac- com modation [5 ], and treatment response to serotonin reuptakeinhibito rs [6] and exposure-based therapies [ 7]. Also, the relationship bet ween OCD, SAD and PD remain tacitly recognized in many diagnostic schemes. For instance, OCD and anxiety disorders were historicallygrouped under“neurotic”conditions by early theorists or simply as “anxiety disorders”across several DSM versions [ 8,9]. In DSM-5, despite the ir“splitting, ”the OCRDs chapter remains straight after anxiety disor- ders as a recognition of their close relationship [ 1]. Lastly, in more recent di agnostic models, such as the Hierarchical Taxonomy Of Psychopathol- ogy (HiTOP) [ 10], OCD and anxiety disorders are described as belonging to the same fear subfactor.

Although OCD and anxiety disorders show many commonalities, the optimal way to conceptualize the association between these conditions is not completely clear (see Fig. 1 ). For instance, whereas some OCD phenotypes (i.e.“shameful”symptoms) seem to result in greater social anxiety [ 11], the performance-only subtype of SAD has bee n more clearly related to panic attacks than the generalized pheno- type [ 12], and certain cognitions ( “fear of dying ”) seem to be shared by PD and OCD [ 13]. Finally, in the “dimensional severity model ”, OCD and anx iety disorders can be considered different expressions of a common diathesis, which could then be represented along a continuum of sever- ity (Model 1c).

In this study, to determine how the relationship between OCD, SAD and PD is best conceptualized (i.e. categorically or dimensionally), we investigated how diagnostic categories and their corresponding symp- toms coaggregate in a transdiagnostic treatment seeking sample. To do so, subjects were assessed with the Mini International Neuropsychi- atric Interview (MINI) to providediagnostic categoriesand a series ofdi- mensionalscales that were decomposed into their subscores to provide information about the presence and severity of different OCD, SAD, and PD symptom domains. Based on the literature supporting increased co- morbidity between OCD and anxiety disorders [ 2], and studies showing that mental disorders (including OCD [ 14–16] and panic disorder [ 17– 19]) may have a history of non-speci ﬁc psychopathology or “pluripo- ten t”[20] yet milder common prodromal symptoms, we predictedtha t the investigated symptom domains [ 1] do not map into their corre- spo nding OCD, SAD, and PD diagnostic categories and [ 2] are less likely to cluster together as they increase in severity.
2. Material and methods
2.1. Participants

The sample for this study included 108 individuals who were diag- nosed with DSM-IV OCD (n= 38); SAD (n= 34) or PD (n= 36) using the Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI) [ 21]. In- clu sion criteria were: (i) a primary diagnosis of OCD, SAD or PD; (ii) age between 18 and 70 years; and (iii) being able to read andﬁll out forms. The exclusion criteria comprised severe mental disorders that could compromise the interpretation of the responses (e.g. mental retarda- tion, current manic or psychotic episodes, or dementia) or severe per- sonality disorders (according to the attending physician). Participants were consecutively recruited from patients who sought treatment in the Obsessive, Compulsive, and Anxiety Research Program and in the Laboratory of Panic and Respiration at the Institute of Psychiatry of Fed- eral University of Rio de Janeiro. If eligible for the present study, the par- ticipants were informed about the study goals and invited to participate. After having signed the consent form, they completed self-report scales in the presence of a psychologist. The research ethics committee of the Institute of Psychiatry of Federal University of Rio de Janeiro has ap- proved this research protocol (CAAE 50308015.1.0000.5263).

2.2. Severity of symptoms

In order to measure the severity of obsessive-compulsive, social anx- iety, and panic symptoms, we employed, respectively, the Brazilian Por- tuguese versions of the Dimensional Obsessive-Compulsive Scale (DOCS), a 20-item self-report scale that provides global as well as spe- ciﬁc scores on concerns about germs and contamination, concernsabout being responsible for harm, injury, or bad luck; unacceptable (taboo) thoughts, and concerns about symmetry, completeness, and the need for things to be“just right”[ 22]; the Social Phobia Inventory (SP IN), a 17-item self-report instrument that, besides providing a global score, generates subscores on fear, avoidance, and physical discomfort [23]; and the Panic and Agoraphobia Scale (PAS), a 13- item self- re port scale that results in total, panic attacks, agoraphobia/avoidant be- haviors, anticipatory anxiety, and disability and worries about health To as sess anxiety sensitivity, the Brazilian Portuguese translation of the Anxiety Sensitivity Index-36 (ASI-36) was employed. The ASI-36 is a 36-item self-report instrument that evaluates fear of anxiety-related cognitions and sensations, and behaviors that are based on beliefs about their harmful consequences, and generates global scores and subscores regarding fears of cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal and neurological symptoms, publicly observable anxiety reactions, and beliefs about cognitive dyscontrol [ 26]. Severities of depressive and anx- ious symptoms were measured with the Brazilian Portuguese versions of the Beck Depression and Anxiety Inventories (BDI and BAI, respec- tively) [ 27]. Whereas the BDI generated low self-esteem, cognitive- affe ctive and somatic subscores [ 28]; BAI total scores were decomposed int o neurophysiologic, subjective, panic and autonomic subscores [ 29]. Eac h of the scales subscores of all scales was split into 3 levels of se- verity (mild, moderate and severe) through K-means clusterization method to obtain minimal variance within each interval of the re- sponses. For example, the ﬁrst subscore of ASI-36 (fear of cardiovascular symptoms) was divided into mild, moderate and severe levels, corre-sponding to scores ranging from 0 to 4; 5 to 13; and 14 to 24 values, re- spectively. This strategy generated an additional 76 variables for our analysis (see Fig. 1 andTable 2 ) other than the diagnostic groups them- selves (OCD, SAD and PD). K-means clusterization was performed by the software “R”(version 3.5.1).
2.3. Statistical analysis

For the analysis of differences between groups in terms of sociodemographic and clinical variables, we computed chi-square tests for dichotomous variables and analyses of variance for continuous variables. If MANOVAs indicated signi ﬁcant group effects, post-hoc con- trasts were computed using Tukey's test. The level of statistical signi ﬁ- cance was 0.05. For these analyses, we used IBM SPSS Statistics Version 25.0 for Mac [ 30].

Our decision to work with symptom domains as qualitative ordinal variables lead to the choice of performing a multiple correspondence analysis (MCA) using the three diagnostic groups and the variables cre- ated from the severity of symptoms as explained above. The choice of this method allows all variables to be analysed simultaneously without the diagnostic restraints required by a bivariate analysis.

Missing values of severity of symptoms were replaced by multiple imputation through the regularized iterative MCA algorithm . The latter strategy guarantees an adequate treatment of the data even with non- random losses below 30%, which would be higher than what occurred in our sample (below than 10%) [ 31]. Both analyses were also per- for med by the software “R”(version 3.5.1) [ 32].

All variables representing the mildest symptoms were grouped without correlating with any particular diagnostic group. Moderate symptoms, however, were more dispersed than milder symptoms, and formed two groups. Aﬁrst one (termed the moderate uncompli- cated“neurotic”group) involved all SPIN, BDI, and DOCS subscores; subscores 1 and 2 of BAI (neurophysiologic and subjective anxieties);subscores 1, 2 and 3 of the PAS (panic attacks, agoraphobic and anticipa- tory anxiety); and subscore 4 of the ASI (fear of publicly observable anx- iety reactions). Thisﬁrst moderate group did not map into any of the three diagnostic categories.

In contrast, a second group (termed moderate complicated“neu- rotic”group) mapped more clearly into PD rather than on OCD or SAD. It included moderate symptoms of subscores 4 and 5 of PAS (dis- ability and worries about health); subscore 4 of BAI (autonomic anxi- ety); and all subscores of ASI with the exception of ASI 4 (including fear of cardiovascular, respiratory, gastric, neurologic and cognitive dyscontrol symptoms). The only moderate symptom variable that did not clearly map into these two groups was subscore 3 of BAI (panic), which also did not map into any speciﬁc diagnostic category.

Finally, all symptom domains of higher severity (here described as the severe dispersed“neurotic”symptom domains.) did not produce a well-deﬁned homogeneous cluster as noted in the previous two groups. Curiously, they also tended to distance themselves from the three diag- nostic categories. Apparently, as severity of OCD and anxiety disorders symptoms increase, they tend to stand as prominent isolated clinical phenomena.
4. Discussion

As research on psychiatric nosology progresses, the validity of DSM diagnostic entities, either as“discrete”categorical conditions and/or as phenotypically homogeneous disorders, are being increasingly chal- lenged. In the present study, we found evidence supporting a predomi- nantly dimensional approach to OCD and anxiety disorders. As predicted, OCD, SAD, and PD symptom domains did not map exactly into their corresponding diagnostic categories but tended to lie within a single spectrum of severity, with milder symptom domains being more likely to cluster together. In particular, symptom domains and dis- orders were grouped into [ 1] a single mild “neurotic ”syndrome charac- terized by multiple, closely related and milder co-occuring symptom domains; [ 2] two moderate (complicated and uncomplicated) “neu- rot ic”syndromes (associated or not with panic disorder, respectively); and [ 3] severe but dispersed “neurotic ”symptom domains.

Ourﬁnd ings supporting the existence of a single spectrum of sever- ity involving all relevant OCD and anxiety disorders symptom domains are consistent with the concept of“general neurotic syndrome”initially proposed by Tyrer et al. as a combination of anxiety and depressivesymptoms associated with anxious, dependent and obsessional person- ality traits, often interspersed with episodes of social anxiety, panic and3 P. In contrast, the mod- er ate“complicated ”group, which was associated with PD (and as such, with increased disability), is the re ﬂection of a spectrum of severity of symptom domains, where the detachment of each other reaches its maximum expression in the “severe ”group.

It could be argued that its small sample size and focus on treatment seeking subjects in different stages of treatment are signi ﬁcant limita- tions of this study. However, a number of additional factors need to besimilarly considered. Firstly, MCA is suf ﬁciently robust to be employed in low numbers. Secondly, treatment seeking samples might be partic- ularly interesting for studies on the relationship between comorbid dis- orders, which seem to be over represented in clinical settings. Finally, although it is tempting to speculate on the existence of a common path- way whereby subjects are ﬁrstly affected by common mild neurotic symptoms to then develop later independent and more speci ﬁc yet in- dependent symptom domains, the cross sectional design of our study does not allow us to make such extrapolation. Future longitudinal stud- ies would be interesting to clarify this important point.
